areas.name: City Hall Römer
areas.description: This former patrician villa with its three-gabled roof has served as Frankfurt's city hall since 1405. It continues to be the seat of the city's Lord Mayor to this day.

areas.name: St bartholomew Cathedral
areas.description: Some people also call it 'Frankfurt's first skyscraper', as the almost 95-metre-high tower of the imperial cathedral was already rising into the sky in the 15th century.

areas.name: St Pauls Church
areas.description: From a place of worship to a monument to democracy: this is where elected representatives drew up the first German constitution from 1848 onwards.

areas.name: Zoo Frankfurt
areas.description: Giraffes in front of the skyline, a jungle atmosphere and the largest nocturnal animal house in Europe: 5,400 animals live in Germany's second oldest zoo in Ostend.

areas.name: Palmengarten Frankfurt
areas.description: For more than 150 years, the Palmengarten has been enchanting visitors with its glass greenhouses and countless native and exotic plants.

areas.name: Skyline viewpoint Deutschherrnbrücke
areas.description: This railway bridge spans 125 metres over the Main- and offers pedestrians a dream panorama of the skyline.

areas.name: Höchst with castle and old town
areas.description: Long a city in its own right, today a neighbourhood with many contrasts: Höchst fascinates with a mix of half-timbered facades, castle, Main promenade - and 'Social Meeting Culture'.

areas.name: Alte Oper
areas.description: After suffering severe damage during World War II, the renovated Alte Oper (Old Opera House) stands as a stunning masterpiece, hosting Broadway-style musicals, jazz ensembles, symphonies, and operas.
